titles.title: Uta no Prince-sama: Maji Love Legend Star
Поющие принцы: легендарная звезда
うたの☆プリンスさまっ♪ マジLOVEレジェンドスター
Utano Princesama: Legend Star
歌之王子殿下 真爱LEGEND STAR

relatedanime.anime: Gekijouban Uta no Prince-sama: Maji Love Kingdom
Uta no Prince-sama: Maji Love Revolutions

anime.description: The six members of ST☆RISH, who have made their shocking idol debut, and Nanami Haruka, who has just begun her career as a composer, have advanced to Saotome Academy`s master course. As they continue their lessons in earnest to learn how to be top idols and composers, they join Shining Agency and begin to work as entertainers. But before that, some senpai idols and strange foreign idols with a few odd habits stand before them, and they end up getting dragged into the race for a mysterious "Newcomer Award." Source: crunchyroll

externalentity.identifier: うたの☆プリンスさまっ♪

tag.name: shoujo
tag.description: In the context of manga and associated media, shoujo, literally meaning "girl", refers to a female audience roughly between the ages of 10 and 18. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: game
tag.description: Based on an interactive (even if minimally so) form of entertainment software, generally available for PCs, consoles or arcade machines.

tag.name: occupation and career
tag.description: The kind of anime which shows the career of a character, usually from the beginning.

tag.name: entertainment industry
tag.description: The show depicts how the entertainment industry works and how the main protagonists strive to cope with the sudden change to fame. At times this can be a very ugly sight indeed.

character.name: Aijima Cecil
character.description: Aijima Cecil is the prince of Agnapolis, a country that`s far west.

character.name: Ootori Eiichi
character.description: Ootori Eiichi is a member of group HEAVENS.

character.name: Sumeragi Kira
character.description: Sumeragi Kira is a member of group HEAVENS.

character.name: Mikado Nagi
character.description: Mikado Nagi is a member of group HEAVENS.

character.name: Raging Ootori
character.description: Raging Ootori is a president of Raging Entertainment company. He is a former top idol and eternal rival with Shining Saotome.

episode.title: JUSTICE IMPULSE
Justice Impulse
Justice Impulse
episode.summary: The second group of the Duet Project is Syo of STARISH and Yamato of HEAVENS. Syo is excited to sing a duet with Hyuga Ryuya`s younger brother, but a powerful rivalry with his older brother surges through Yamato`s heart. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Mighty Aura
Might Aura
Mighty Aura
episode.summary: The top starters of the Duet Project are Tokiya of STARISH and Eiji of HEAVENS. Tokiya and Haruka approach their unknown rival with nervousness, but surprisingly they`re met by the voice of an angel... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: KIZUNA
Kizuna
Kizuna
episode.summary: The members of STARISH and HEAVENS are shocked to learn they will be singing duets with members from the other group to prepare for the decisive concert. Meanwhile, QUARTET NIGHT appears to be experiencing some discord of its own. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 夢を歌へと...!
Turning Dreams Into Music!
Yume o Uta e to...?
episode.summary: When QUARTET NIGHT is chosen to perform as the Triple S Opening Artist, they decline the opportunity after STARISH and HEAVENS give equally compelling performances. Raging Otori and Shining Saotome propose another musical showdown to determine the opening artist between the three groups in which all three of them must sing songs written by Haruka! Who will win the decisive concert and the honor of performing at the Triple S? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Lasting Oneness
Lasting Oneness
Lasting Oneness
episode.summary: Due to their inborn earnestness and similar backgrounds, Masato and Kira both sense how compatible they are with one another. However, while work on the song is going smoothly, Kira fears something is lacking. Meanwhile, Masato receives word from his family... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Grown empathy
Grown Empathy
Grown Empathy
episode.summary: At their meeting for the Duet Project, Nagi`s casual remark causes a sudden change in Natsuki`s positive behavior. From Natsuki`s words and past videos, Nagi realizes his secret... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Lovely Eyes
Lovely Eyes
Lovely Eyes
episode.summary: The fourth duo of the Duet Project are Ren of STARISH and Van of HEAVENS who are also slated to play rivals in a TV drama. When Van begins aggressively pursuing Haruka, Ren heads straight into battle with his own passionate feelings hidden in his heart. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Visible Elf
Visible Elf
Visible Elf
episode.summary: The third duo of the Duet Project are Cecil of STARISH and Shion of HEAVENS. Trying to follow up on Tokiya and Syo`s success, Cecil aggressively approaches the project, but Shion closes off his heart more and more as though in response to Cecil`s passion. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Three shining stars
Three Shining Stars
Three Shining Stars
episode.summary: The emotions and hoeps of STARISH, QUARTET NIGHT, and HEAVENS are illuminated by a morning sun rising in a clear sky. As Haruka prays for similar things, the Decisive Concert is about to begin. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 未来, 夢, ありがとう... そして!
The Future, Dreams, Thank You: And!
Mirai, Yume, Arigatou... Soshite!
episode.summary: After reuniting in the sunflower field, STARISH successfully makes it to their live broadcast while becoming the talk of the town. With the Duet Project finished, STARISH and HEAVENS are set to start working towards the Decisive Concert. However, a plot to drive them towards despair is approaching. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: We believe you
We Believe You
We Believe You
episode.summary: Leaving behind a completed duet, Otoya disappears. Having been exposed to a side of Otoya they`d never known before through his voice, as the members of STARISH search for clues that will lead them to Otoya, they arrive at the truth behind his personal history. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: NEXT DOOR
Next Door
Next Door
episode.summary: The theme of Otoya and Eiichi`s song is a "soul-shaking song." When Eiichi explains to Otoya that he must face his true self that exists deep inside his heart to do so, he stoically engages in writing the lyrics. However, gradually he becomes less and less like himself. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: WE ARE ST☆RISH!!
We Are Starish!!
We Are Starish!!
episode.summary: QUARTET NIGHT and HEAVENS have finished their own brilliant performances, which leaves only STARISH. Will their performance match the passion of the other two groups? Who will be chosen to perform as the Triple S opening artist? Source: crunchyroll
